headline: New Zealand Economy Shrinks 0.9%, Sparking Heated Debate on Government's Performance
summary: Parliament was dominated by news of a significant economic contraction, leading to tense exchanges between the Government and Opposition over fiscal management. The day also saw a contentious debate on a bill to remove advertising restrictions on public holidays, and a Green MP delivered an emotional valedictory speech, resigning due to threats against their family.

topicSummaries.topic: Economy Contracts by 0.9%, Government and Opposition Clash Over Causes
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This official measure of economic activity directly impacts job security, household incomes, and the cost of living for all New Zealanders.
topicSummaries.content: The Minister for Economic Growth, Nicola Willis, faced intense questioning from Labour's Damien O'Connor after official figures revealed the economy shrank by 0.9% in the latest quarter. O'Connor challenged the Minister on her government's performance, citing a 9.4% decline in construction and comparing New Zealand's negative growth to positive results in Australia, Japan, and the UK. Minister Willis defended her record, pointing to 0.8% growth in the first quarter of the year and stating she could not take responsibility for decisions made by the previous government but was focused on 'fixing it'.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Damien O'Connor (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Does she agree with Nicola Willis in 2022, when GDP shrunk by 0.2 percent, that "Today's release of GDP data is more bad news for New Zealanders already struggling with the cost of living crisis"; and if so, what would she say now that GDP figures published today show a 0.9 percent decline?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (Minister for Economic Growth)
keyExchanges.quote: It is the case that I cannot take responsibility for all the decisions made in the years leading up to my period as Minister of Finance. What I can take responsibility for is fixing it. What I can also say, quite confidently, is that things would be a heck of a lot worse if you lot were in charge.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Allow Holiday Advertising Passes Committee Stage Amid Media Crisis
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This legislation would remove longstanding bans on TV and radio advertising on days like Christmas and Anzac Day, changing what New Zealanders see and hear on public holidays.
topicSummaries.content: The Broadcasting (Repeal of Advertising Restrictions) Amendment Bill was debated in the committee of the whole House, passing without amendment. The bill repeals a section of the 1989 Broadcasting Act that prohibits advertising on TV and radio on Christmas Day, Good Friday, Easter Sunday, and Anzac Day morning. The Government, represented by Hon Chris Penk, argued the change was necessary to create fairness and consistency for traditional broadcasters competing with online platforms where no such restrictions exist. Labour and Green MPs questioned the bill's effectiveness, arguing the estimated $6 million in extra revenue was a minor solution to the media sector's major financial crisis and raising concerns about the commercialisation of sacred days.

keyExchanges.speaker: Reuben Davidson (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: What this shows us is that this repeal, in and of itself, is a very, very small and limited bill that has a very, very minor impact on the broadcasting sector... the title and the title clause feels like it doesn't give adequate acknowledgment to the depth of the challenges and to the small scale of the financial return that a shift like this will bring for the sector.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Penk (Minister for Building and Construction)
keyExchanges.quote: The content of this very short bill is to repeal advertising restrictions. It's appropriate, therefore, that its title is "Repeal of Advertising Restrictions". Anything more or less than that would be remiss on the part of the Minister, and I'm pleased that he has gone for a very descriptive, straightforward title.

topicSummaries.topic: Coalition Tensions Exposed Over New Zealand's Stance on Palestinian Statehood
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: Public disagreement between senior ministers raises questions about the government's foreign policy coherence and credibility on the world stage.
topicSummaries.content: During Question Time, Labour's Carmel Sepuloni pressed Deputy Prime Minister David Seymour on the Government's position regarding the recognition of Palestinian statehood and the conflict in Gaza. Sepuloni highlighted recent comments from the Minister of Foreign Affairs, who stated Seymour was "talking out of his field" and had "no authority" to make statements on the issue. Seymour defended the coalition's ability to function despite differing party views, describing the government as "dangerously united." He stated that the Government is taking a "deliberative view" on the matter and will announce its position soon.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Was the Minister of Foreign Affairs correct when he said that David Seymour's statement regarding the recognition of Palestinian Statehood "was made by someone who's got no authority to make it."?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (Deputy Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: On behalf of the Prime Minister, it is certainly correct that the authority to make that statement on behalf of the Government rests with the Minister of Foreign Affairs. However, it is also true that this is a Government of three different parties, with leaders who each lead a party with its own identity, and, from the point of view of the Opposition, this Government is dangerously united.

topicSummaries.topic: Fisheries Minister Labels Māui Dolphin a 'Mythological Creature'
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The Minister's comments on a critically endangered species signal a potential shift in environmental and fisheries policy, concerning conservation groups.
topicSummaries.content: In a tense exchange with Green MP Teanau Tuiono, Minister for Oceans and Fisheries Shane Jones caused a stir with his comments on the critically endangered Māui dolphin. When asked about policies to protect the species, including a moratorium on set-net and trawl fishing, Jones referred to it as a "mythological creature." He argued that restrictive measures have had a significant impact on the viability of the fisheries sector and later stated he would not be "guilt-tripped about mythical creatures living off the west coast of Taranaki."

keyExchanges.speaker: Teanau Tuiono (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: What are his policies for protecting the health of the Māui dolphins, and will he agree to a moratorium on set-nets and trawl fishing within their habitats, and if he does not agree, why is that?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Shane Jones (Minister for Oceans and Fisheries)
keyExchanges.quote: Over the years, a host of restrictive measures have been put in place for this mythological creature sadly known as the Māui dolphin. This has had a significant impact on the ability and the viability of the fisheries sector, but we should not devalue the work that has already taken place on the west coast of Te Ikaroa-a-Māui to provide remedial measures for this declining population of mythical Hector's dolphins.

topicSummaries.topic: Green MP Benjamin Doyle Resigns, Citing 'Violent and Toxic' Threats
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: An MP's resignation due to threats against their family's safety raises serious questions about the state of political discourse and security for public figures in New Zealand.
topicSummaries.content: In a powerful valedictory statement, Green MP Benjamin Doyle announced their resignation from Parliament, stating they were choosing to put their child first after facing threats to their life and safety. Doyle described Parliament as a "hostile and toxic place" and detailed the real-world impacts of political life, including having to remove their child from school and avoid public spaces. The speech served as a sharp critique of the political system's culture and the personal cost of public service, particularly for those who do not fit a traditional mould.

keyExchanges.speaker: Benjamin Doyle (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: I have felt firsthand the unbelievable impact that being here can have on a person and those they love. I have seen that play out in violent, toxic, and real-world ways. No person should have to remove their child from school due to threats to their life.

keyExchanges.speaker: Benjamin Doyle (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: I am willing to put my love for these things before my own needs; and even my own safety, but no love is more compelling than that which we hold for our tamariki, and I cannot continue to put this work before the needs of my own child.

conclusion: The day was defined by a clash over the country's negative economic direction, while a Green MP's resignation over safety threats cast a shadow over the political climate.
